qas.question: What calendar did Turkey use before 1917 for general purposes?
What calendar did Turkey utilize for fiscal purposes?
Where did Turkey start the fiscal year?
When did Turkey begin to use the Gregorian calendar for fiscal means?
When did Turkey start using the Gregorian calendar for all purposes?
Who use the lunar Islamic calendar until the nineteenth century?
Who use the Hegira era is a fiscal calendar?
What was used to set the year number?
What was needed because the lunar year is longer than the solar year?
What did Turkey start using for all purposes on March 1, 1917?

context: Prior to 1917, <b5_0><b6_0>Turkey<b6_0/><b5_0/> used the <a0_0>lunar Islamic<a0_0/> calendar with the Hegira era for general purposes and the <a1_0>Julian<a1_0/> calendar for fiscal purposes. The start of the fiscal year was eventually fixed at <a2_0>1 March<a2_0/> and the year number was roughly equivalent to <b7_0>the Hegira year<b7_0/> (see Rumi calendar). As the solar year is longer than the lunar year this originally entailed the use of <b8_0>"escape years"<b8_0/> every so often when the number of the fiscal year would jump. From <a3_0>1 March 1917<a3_0/> the fiscal year became Gregorian, rather than Julian. On <a4_0>1 January 1926<a4_0/> the use of the <b9_0>Gregorian calendar<b9_0/> was extended to include use for general purposes and the number of the year became the same as in other countries.
